Hi David,

I have started to write a tool by myself.
I'm parsing the junitr=
eport XML file generated by ant using Castor.
Castor is also used as a JDO/=
OR-mapping tool to write/read data from 
the underlying MySQL database. It =
looks quite promising.
I have now started to create a Swing GUI as the cent=
ral user 
interface for this tool. So, I'm able to mark different junitrepo=
rt 
results with a label that identifies the JVM, Operating system and 
int=
egration build number (together with the subversion/Clearcase 
label) used =
to run the tests.
For trend analysis I will generate charts using JFreeChar=
t or 
StyleReportPro.

--Klaus

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kamal2222ahm=
ed" <Kamal.Ahmed@w...> 
wrote:

> > >

 something like this a while ago, but it was

> parsed

ext output files.  I imagine that you could probably 
write 
> > > somethin=
g to do this yourself as quickly as extracting the
> interesting 
> > > par=
ts from my code.

ld be looking for 
in a 
> > > trend analysis?  Thanks,

vid Saff

 >>I know, JUnit 'unit' tests should always pass ;-) But we are 
using the
=

So fro=
m
> > >>time to time, in this area something may go wrong. Therefore 
I'm
>=
 > >>looking for a tool, that generates a report showing only the
> > >>dif=
ferences between current and last JUnit report - which 
failing
> > >>tests=
 were fixed, which tests stopped to pass, which tests 
were added
> > >>and=
 which removed. Additionaly a test trend analysis should be
> > >>possible.=

> > >>I know, parsing the XML junitreport output and generating the=
 
info,

anyone

p 
in this
